prompts:
Python syntax question: What’s the difference between '==' and 'is'? Given this code:

a = [1, 2, 3]
b = a
c = [1, 2, 3]
print(a == b, a is b)
print(a == c, a is c)

Why do these printouts differ, and when should I use 'is' vs '=='?

TypeScript compile error with strict null checks. Here's a minimal example:

tsconfig has "strict": true.

Code:
interface User { name?: string }
const u: User = {};
const s: string = u.name; // TS2322: Type 'string | undefined' is not assignable to type 'string'.

Why does this fail, and what's the correct way to fix it (without turning off strictNullChecks)?
Explain the difference between a stack and a queue in simple terms, and show a tiny Python example of push/pop vs enqueue/dequeue using lists. Keep the explanation to a few sentences.
Walk me through binary search on this sorted list: [2, 5, 9, 12, 17, 23, 31] to find the target 23. Show the low, mid, and high indices at each step and the final index you return.

Please convert the following list of names from the format "LASTNAME, First M." (with inconsistent spacing) into "First M. Lastname" with proper capitalization. If there is no middle initial, omit it. Remove any extra spaces. Output one name per line in the same order.

Data:
- SMITH,   John A.
-   o'neill,  maeve
- GARCIA,LUIS
- nguyen,  thAnH   t.

Can you extract all the email addresses from the text below, convert them to lowercase, remove duplicates, sort them alphabetically, and return them as a single comma-separated line?

Text:
"Ping Alex at A.Parker+dev@Example.com and cc ops-team@example.com. If that bounces, try parker@EXAMPLE.com, support@example.org, or info+news@example.org. Also note: a.parker+DEV@example.com was used before."

Using Python's re module, can you help me write a single regex that matches dates in exactly these formats and captures them with named groups year, month, and day?
- YYYY-MM-DD (e.g., 2025-01-09)
- DD/MM/YYYY (e.g., 09/01/2025)
- Month DD, YYYY (e.g., Jan 9, 2025 or December 12, 2024; month names should be case-insensitive)
It should NOT match 2025/01/09, 9-1-2025, or 09 Jan 2025.
Please provide the regex (Python syntax) and list the matches with their captured groups for this text:

Error on 2025-01-09 when job ran.
Maintenance scheduled for 09/01/2025 at 05:00.
Birthday: Jan 9, 2025 — don’t forget!
Meeting moved to December 12, 2024 due to weather.
Not a date: 2025/01/09
Another: 9-1-2025
We also saw 09 Jan 2025 mentioned somewhere.

I need a JavaScript-compatible regex to validate US phone numbers with these rules:
- Optional country code +1
- Separators can be spaces or dashes
- Area code may be in parentheses
- Optional extension like x89 or ext. 234
Please provide one regex and briefly explain how it works. Also indicate which of these should match vs not match:

Should match:
+1 (212) 555-7890
212-555-7890
(415)555 2671
646 555 1234 x89
+1-917-555-0000 ext. 234

Should NOT match:
+2 212 555 7890
(212 555-7890
212) 555-7890
555-7890
212-555-78901
212-555-ABCD

Write a Python snippet that opens a text file named 'notes.txt', reads it line by line, strips whitespace, ignores empty lines and lines starting with '#', and returns a list of the remaining lines. Handle the case where the file doesn't exist by printing a clear error to stderr without crashing. Please include the code and a one-paragraph explanation.

Using Node.js with fs/promises, implement an async function updateConfig(path, patch) that reads a JSON file at 'path', shallow-merges keys from the plain object 'patch' into it, and writes it back with 2-space indentation. If the file has invalid JSON, reject with a helpful error message. Show the function and a short example of calling it.

Parse this XML catalog and return a JSON array of books published in or after 2019. For each, include: id (from the book's id attribute), title, author, genre (lowercased), price (numeric), and currency (from price/@currency). Use the original currency; don't convert values.

XML:
<catalog>
  <book id="bk101" genre="fiction">
    <title>After the Storm</title>
    <author>Linda Grey</author>
    <year>2014</year>
    <price currency="USD">12.99</price>
  </book>
  <book id="bk102" genre="nonfiction">
    <title>Data Made Simple</title>
    <author>R. Shah</author>
    <year>2019</year>
    <price currency="USD">29.50</price>
  </book>
  <book id="bk103" genre="fiction">
    <title>Silent River</title>
    <author>K. Mori</author>
    <year>2021</year>
    <price currency="EUR">18.00</price>
  </book>
</catalog>

Help me design a relational schema for an online course platform with these features: users can be students or instructors; instructors create courses; courses have modules and lessons; students enroll in courses; each lesson can have quizzes with multiple questions; students submit quiz answers and get scores; students can leave a 1–5 star course review with a comment; track created_at/updated_at on all records. Please propose: (1) a list of tables with key columns (generic data types are fine), primary keys, and foreign keys; (2) notes on many-to-many join tables; and (3) three indexes you’d add. Keep the answer concise (bulleted is fine).

I’m building an event ticketing system that supports both reserved seating and general admission. Can you sketch a concise SQL schema outline? Requirements: venues have sections/rows/seats; an event occurs at a venue and may be seated or GA; tickets belong to an order and either reference a specific seat or a GA allocation bucket; prevent double-selling the same seat for the same event; track ticket status (reserved, paid, canceled, refunded). Please list the tables with key columns, PK/FK definitions, any composite unique constraints needed to enforce seat uniqueness per event, and 2–3 suggested indexes. No full DDL needed.

Write a PostgreSQL query that returns, for each customer segment, the average order value (AOV) over the last 90 days, excluding orders with status in ('cancelled', 'refunded'). Return columns: segment, orders_count, total_revenue, avg_order_value. Use now() as current time. Schema:

customers (
  id BIGINT PRIMARY KEY,
  name TEXT,
  segment TEXT
)

orders (
  id BIGINT PRIMARY KEY,
  customer_id BIGINT REFERENCES customers(id),
  order_date TIMESTAMP,
  status TEXT,
  total_amount NUMERIC(12,2)
)

Can you write a SQL Server query to list the top 10 movies by average rating for titles released since 2015, only if they have at least 50 reviews? Return columns: movie_title, director_name, reviews_count, avg_rating (rounded to 2 decimals). Exclude NULL ratings. Schemas:

movies (
  id INT PRIMARY KEY,
  title NVARCHAR(255),
  release_date DATE,
  director_id INT
)

directors (
  id INT PRIMARY KEY,
  full_name NVARCHAR(255)
)

reviews (
  id INT PRIMARY KEY,
  movie_id INT,
  rating INT -- 1 to 10, may be NULL
)

Django ORM question: Given these models, what's the idiomatic way to (1) annotate each Author with the number of published Books in the last 365 days, (2) order authors by that count descending, and (3) prefetch ONLY those recent published books to avoid N+1?

from django.db import models
from django.utils import timezone

class Author(models.Model):
    name = models.CharField(max_length=200)

class Book(models.Model):
    author = models.ForeignKey(Author, on_delete=models.CASCADE, related_name="books")
    title = models.CharField(max_length=200)
    published = models.BooleanField(default=False)
    published_at = models.DateTimeField(null=True, blank=True)

Please show a single QuerySet example using annotate/Prefetch that I can run in a view.

I'm designing a REST API for an online bookstore. Resources: books, authors, and orders. Needs: CRUD for books and authors; create/read orders (no update/delete); list books with pagination and filtering by authorId, genre, and inStock; standard HTTP status codes; and a simple, consistent error body. Please propose endpoint paths and methods, show a minimal JSON schema for each resource, and an example of the error format. Keep the answer under 200 words.

Here’s my draft API for a notes app (not very RESTful): GET /getNotes, GET /getNote?id=123, POST /createNote, PUT /updateNote?id=123, DELETE /deleteNote?id=123, POST /users/login. Notes have id, title, body, tags; users own notes. Could you rewrite this as a RESTful design with resource-oriented paths and methods, including how to: model note ownership under /users, filter notes by tag, and handle authentication routes? Brief bullets are fine.

Please call the OpenWeatherMap API to get the current weather in Oslo, NO (metric units) and summarize: temperature (°C), weather description, wind speed (m/s). Use my API key: 7e9b0f0c8f23456789abcd1234567890. Endpoint: GET https://api.openweathermap.org/data/2.5/weather?q=Oslo,NO&units=metric&appid=7e9b0f0c8f23456789abcd1234567890
Fetch the top 3 front-page stories from Hacker News via the Algolia API and return only title and URL for each. Endpoint: GET https://hn.algolia.com/api/v1/search?tags=front_page&hitsPerPage=3
I'm new to backend dev. Can you explain the difference between authentication and authorization, and give a simple web app example that shows both?
For a small single-page app with a Node.js backend, should I use server sessions with cookies or JWT-based tokens? In a few bullet points, compare the trade-offs and common pitfalls for each.

My SPA is served from S3 behind CloudFront. Some users keep getting a stale app.js after deploy. Current headers:
- index.html: Cache-Control: public, max-age=86400; ETag present
- app.js/app.css: Cache-Control: public, max-age=604800; no cache-busting in filenames
I only invalidate index.html on deploy. What caching/header strategy and asset naming would you recommend to avoid stale bundles (e.g., hashed filenames, immutable, shorter HTML TTL), and do I need additional CloudFront invalidations? Please keep the steps concise.

I’m building a React 18 app with Vite. The initial load on mobile is slow (Lighthouse ~48, FCP ~3.8s, TTI ~7s). The app has a large product grid (1,000+ items with images), uses React Router, Zustand, Tailwind, axios, and dayjs. Images come from a CDN. The gzipped bundle is ~480KB and the vendor chunk is big. I can’t switch frameworks. What are the top 6 high-impact, low-effort performance optimizations I can try right now to speed up initial load and make scrolling smoother?

Help me speed up this Postgres 15 query on a table with ~5M rows.

Table: orders(id bigserial PK, user_id int, status text, total_cents int, created_at timestamptz, updated_at timestamptz)
Query:
SELECT user_id, COUNT(*) AS cnt
FROM orders
WHERE status = 'paid' AND created_at >= now() - interval '30 days'
GROUP BY user_id
ORDER BY cnt DESC
LIMIT 20;

Indexes: PK on id, btree on (user_id). What are the most likely indexing and query tweaks to make this fast, plus any practical config hints? Keep it to a handful of specific tips.

Go goroutines: this sometimes hangs. Can you point out the deadlock and show a concise fix (either enforce lock ordering or use a single lock)? A short explanation plus a corrected snippet is enough.

Code:
package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "sync"
    "time"
)

var mu1 sync.Mutex
var mu2 sync.Mutex

func f1() {
    mu1.Lock()
    defer mu1.Unlock()
    time.Sleep(10 * time.Millisecond)
    mu2.Lock()
    mu2.Unlock()
}

func f2() {
    mu2.Lock()
    defer mu2.Unlock()
    time.Sleep(10 * time.Millisecond)
    mu1.Lock()
    mu1.Unlock()
}

func main() {
    go f1()
    go f2()
    time.Sleep(1 * time.Second)
    fmt.Println("done (may hang)")
}

Can you show a minimal Python 3.11 asyncio pattern to fetch a list of URLs with a max of 3 concurrent requests using aiohttp? Requirements:
- return a list of (url, status_code or None)
- set a 5s per-request timeout without cancelling other tasks
- ensure the client session closes properly
Use these sample URLs: ['https://httpbin.org/status/200','https://httpbin.org/delay/10','https://httpbin.org/status/404','https://nosuch.example.invalid']

What’s a solid set of unit testing best practices for a medium-size Python service using pytest? In a concise answer, please cover: tests folder layout and file naming, Arrange–Act–Assert structure and test naming style, when to use fixtures vs factory helpers, parametrizing edge cases, mocking external HTTP calls (e.g., requests) with autospecced mocks, and tips to avoid flaky tests and keep them fast. A short example showing how to mock requests.get would help.

Help me set up integration tests for a Node.js Express API that uses Prisma with PostgreSQL. I want to run the tests locally and in GitHub Actions. Please provide:
- A quick outline of the steps
- Minimal jest.config and package.json scripts
- A tiny example test using Supertest that hits GET /health and a /users endpoint (assume /users returns 200)
- How to spin up a test Postgres with Docker and run `prisma migrate` before tests
- A minimal GitHub Actions job using the postgres service
Keep it concise—only the smallest working snippets.

How do I configure integration testing for a Spring Boot 3 REST app with PostgreSQL using JUnit 5 and Testcontainers? Please include:
- The minimal Maven dependencies and a short application-test.properties
- A single @SpringBootTest test that starts Postgres with Testcontainers and verifies a simple repository call
- Any notes to make it run in CI on GitHub Actions where Docker is available
Keep the answer brief with tiny code samples only.

Write a compact GitHub Actions workflow (YAML only, please) for this Node.js repo:

Repo layout:
- package.json
- pnpm-lock.yaml
- src/
- test/

Requirements:
- Trigger on pushes to main and on pull_request
- Matrix build on Node 18 and 20
- Use pnpm with proper caching of the pnpm store
- Steps: checkout, setup Node, install deps, run tests, then build
- Upload coverage/lcov.info as an artifact named coverage-node${{ matrix.node-version }}
- Only run when files under src/**, test/**, package.json, or pnpm-lock.yaml change
- Name the workflow "CI" and the file would live at .github/workflows/ci.yml
- Keep it under ~60 lines

Please provide a minimal .gitlab-ci.yml for a Dockerized Python (3.12) app:

- stages: test, build
- test job: use python:3.12 image, cache pip based on requirements.txt, install with pip -r requirements.txt, run pytest -q
- build job: runs only on main branch, depends on test, uses docker:stable with dind service, logs in to registry using GitLab CI predefined variables, builds image tagged $CI_REGISTRY_IMAGE:$CI_COMMIT_SHORT_SHA and also latest, then pushes both
- Only run pipeline when files in app/** or requirements.txt or Dockerfile change
- Return just the YAML, around 40 lines or fewer

I'm on a local branch feature/login with 5 commits. origin/main has moved ahead since I branched. Our team prefers a linear history and we squash-merge PRs. What's the safest way to update my branch before opening a PR: rebase onto origin/main or merge origin/main into my branch? Please give concise, step-by-step commands (fetch, rebase/merge, resolve conflicts, push — including whether to use --force-with-lease) and how to abort/undo if something goes wrong.

We're using GitFlow (branches: master and develop). Production is currently tag v2.3.0 on master. I need to ship hotfix v2.3.1 containing a single change from commit 9f8a1b2. Can you list the exact git commands to: create the hotfix branch from v2.3.0, cherry-pick 9f8a1b2, bump version, run tests (assume npm test), merge the hotfix back into master and develop, create and push tag v2.3.1, and push all branches/tags to origin? Keep it concise.

I'm stuck on a Poetry dependency conflict. Here's my pyproject.toml:

[tool.poetry]
name = "demo-app"
version = "0.1.0"
description = ""
authors = ["Me <me@example.com>"]

[tool.poetry.dependencies]
python = "^3.10"
requests = "^2.31"
boto3 = "^1.26.120"
urllib3 = "^2.0"

[build-system]
requires = ["poetry-core>=1.5.0"]
build-backend = "poetry.core.masonry.api"

When I run `poetry update` I get:
Resolving dependencies...
Because boto3 (1.26.120) depends on botocore (>=1.29.120,<1.30.0) which depends on urllib3 (>=1.25.4,<1.27), and urllib3 (2.0.7) is incompatible with <1.27, version solving failed.

What’s the cleanest way to resolve this while keeping requests up to date? Should I remove my explicit urllib3 pin, constrain it to <1.27, or change boto3? Also, which Poetry commands should I run to update the lockfile correctly?

NPM peer dependency trouble after bumping ESLint. My package.json dev deps:

{
  "name": "eslint-demo",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "devDependencies": {
    "eslint": "^9.0.0",
    "eslint-plugin-react": "^7.34.0",
    "eslint-config-airbnb": "^19.0.4"
  }
}

`npm install` output:

npm ERR! Could not resolve dependency:
npm ERR! peer eslint@"^8" from eslint-plugin-react@7.34.0
npm ERR! node_modules/eslint-plugin-react
npm ERR!   dev eslint-plugin-react@"^7.34.0" from the root project

What’s the simplest fix here—downgrade ESLint to ^8, or upgrade plugins/configs to versions compatible with ESLint 9? Please suggest specific versions or commands to get a clean install.

I’m setting up Vite for a React 18 + TypeScript project. Please give me a minimal vite.config.ts and tsconfig.json that:
- supports JSX/TSX
- sets a path alias @ to ./src
- lets me import SVGs as React components (SVGR)
- uses base '/app/' for both dev and build
- runs the dev server on port 5174
- outputs builds to dist/app
I’m using @vitejs/plugin-react and vite-plugin-svgr. Project structure: src/main.tsx, src/App.tsx, and index.html at the repo root. Assume Node 18+. Keep the configs short and include a one-sentence explanation of any non-obvious option.

Please write a single top-level CMakeLists.txt for this C++ project:
root/
  src/
    main.cpp
    lib/
      util.cpp
      util.h
  tests/
    util_tests.cpp
Requirements:
- CMake 3.20+ and C++20
- Build a static library 'utils' from src/lib/*.cpp and an executable 'app' from src/main.cpp that links 'utils'
- Enable warnings: -Wall -Wextra -Wpedantic for GCC/Clang; /W4 for MSVC
- Add option BUILD_TESTS (default ON) to fetch Catch2 v3 via FetchContent, build tests in tests/, and register them with ctest
Keep it concise and self-contained.

I’m new to Docker. For this tiny Flask app, please write the simplest possible Dockerfile and the exact docker build and docker run commands to: build an image named hello-flask:1.0, publish port 5000 on the host to 5000 in the container, set env var FLASK_ENV=production, and mount the current project directory read-only into /app. Keep explanations brief.

Here is the app code:

app.py
```python
from flask import Flask
app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route('/')
def hello():
    return 'Hello from Flask!'

if __name__ == '__main__':
    app.run(host='0.0.0.0', port=5000)
```

requirements.txt
```
flask==3.0.0
```

Help me understand what this command does, in simple Docker terms:

docker run -d --name web -p 8080:80 nginx:alpine

Please explain what the image vs container are here, what the -p 8080:80 mapping means, and what happens to files I add under /usr/share/nginx/html if I remove the container. Then show one command to run it again so that /usr/share/nginx/html is persisted using a named volume.

I'm brand new to Azure. I have a tiny Flask app (files: app.py and requirements.txt) that listens on port 8000 and uses two env vars: FLASK_ENV=production and SECRET_KEY. Can you give me the simplest step-by-step to deploy it from my GitHub repo to Azure App Service (Linux), including how to set those environment variables, turn on application logging, and add a staging deployment slot? Also, what's a budget-friendly App Service plan tier for testing?

On Google Cloud, I want to deploy a containerized HTTP service. Can you briefly compare Cloud Run, GKE, and Compute Engine for this (cost, ops effort, and when to choose each), then give me the minimal gcloud commands to build and deploy a sample container to Cloud Run in us-central1 with unauthenticated access? Assume I have a Dockerfile in the current directory.

I'm using Vue 3 with Pinia and want a simple cart store that:
- tracks items as [{ id, title, price, qty }]
- exposes derived getters: total and itemCount
- persists to localStorage across reloads
- has actions: addItem(id, title, price), removeItem(id), clear()

Can you show a compact Pinia store implementation and how to wire up persistence (either a plugin or store.$subscribe)? A tiny usage example in a component would help. Please keep the code minimal.

Why isn’t my sticky header sticking? In this layout the content area scrolls, but the header doesn’t stay at the top. Can you point out what’s wrong and suggest a minimal CSS change to make the header stick without switching to position: fixed? HTML: ```html
Header

Lots of content...

More content...

Even more content...

``` CSS: ```css html, body { height: 100%; margin: 0; } .wrapper { height: 100vh; overflow: hidden; } .site-header { position: sticky; top: 0; background: #fff; padding: 16px; border-bottom: 1px solid #ccc; } .content { height: 100%; overflow-y: auto; padding: 16px; } ```

Flexbox spacing question: I’m using flex-wrap with space-between, but the gaps look weird when the last row has fewer items. I want consistent 24px gaps between cards on all rows and left-aligned rows. What’s the simplest CSS tweak (no extra markup)? HTML: ```html
  • A
  • B
  • C
  • D
  • E
``` CSS: ```css .cards { display: flex; flex-wrap: wrap; justify-content: space-between; list-style: none; padding: 0; margin: 0; } .card { width: 220px; height: 120px; background: #eee; margin-bottom: 24px; display: grid; place-items: center; } ```

I'm deciding between native (Kotlin/Swift), React Native, and Flutter for a simple mobile app that needs GPS, camera access, and offline data. Can you explain the key differences, main pros/cons, the learning curve for a solo beginner, and which you’d recommend?

I just installed Android Studio on Windows. What are the minimal steps to create and run a "Hello World" app on an emulator, and what do MainActivity.kt and activity_main.xml each do? Keep it simple, please.
